Key Arguments: The proposed legislation is seen as a form of censorship that limits free speech and the sharing of opposing opinions.
The author believes that misinformation and disinformation do not pose a threat as stated in the bill's preamble.
There is a concern that the legislation would prevent scientific and societal progress by restricting alternative viewpoints.
The author argues that existing laws are sufficient to protect against harm and that the bill is unnecessary.
The submission suggests that the legislation would lead to a 'police state' and is a threat to democracy and freedom of speech.
The author questions the independence of ACMA, suggesting it would act as a government tool to control truth.
Notable Quotes: We will have no scientific advances and we will be living in a police state if the only truth we are allowed to hear is what ACMA or the government decides is the truth.
This limiting of the sharing of information Bill is the biggest threat to our democracy and freedom of speech that we have ever faced.
Trusting experts is not a feature of science, and it is not a feature of democracy. It is a feature of religion and totalitarianism.
The government and ACMA were never appointed by we the people to be the arbiters of truth.
